acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 2 from 72-hour ErC50=5.6mg/L of algae (Scenedesmus) (IUCLID, 2000).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Dermal toxicity LD50 of a rabbit is 67mg/kg (IUCLID (2000)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: There are descriptions about LC50 = 0.3mg/L (but exposure time is unknown) (RTECS (2000)) and that death was observed with 1 hour exposure to 7.5ppm (ACGIH (2001)). Soit is supposed to be Category 1.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: SPECIES: Rat ENDPOINT: LD50 VALUE: 71mg/kg REFERENCE SOURCE: ACGIH (2001), RTECS (2004)

carcinogenicity.rationale: ACGIH is classified into A4 and there is also data in which carcinogenicity is not indicated in an animal examination. But there is the proof it is carcinogenic to humans in epidemiological data (PATTY (5th, 2005)). So it is set as Category 1.

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classified into Category 2, since acute toxicity was Category 2, and rapid degradability is unknown, though supposed less bio-accumulative (log Kow=0.03(PHYSPROP Database, 2005)).

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: There are negative results from the in vivo (multi-generation) reciprocal translocation test in mice, mouse chromosome aberration test and dominant lethal test ((PATTY (5th, 2001)) and from the DNA damage test in rats (IUCLID (2000)), but there are positive results from in vivo chromosome aberration tests in rat bone-marrow (inhalation). There are also positive results from the in vitro (CHO) chromosome aberration test, the sister chromatid exchange test and the Ames test (PATTY (5th, 2001)). So the substance was classified as Category 2.

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen and chlorine (but not fluorine) and these elements are chemically bonded only to carbon and hydrogen (but not to other elements).

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not ignite spontaneously on coming into contact with air at normal temperatures

reproductive_toxicity.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
reproductive_toxicity.rationale: There is effect to embryo in animal experiment even if it is limited result (DFGOT vol. 5 (1993)), it is doubted about reproductive toxicity to human

respiratory_sensitizer.rationale: There is no data and it cannot be classified..

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive or self-reactive properties present in the molecule.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: The result which is irritating is obtained in the animal studies (IUCLID (2000)). Although PATTY (5th, 2005) is setting to extremly irritating. But there is no evidence as irreversible, it is set as Category 2A.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Results as both being irritating and not irritating is obtained in animal examination (IUCLID (2000)). But PATTY (5th, 2005) states that there is no skin irritation.

skin_sensitizer.rationale: There is proof that there is no skin sensitization by animal studies etc. (PATTY (5th, 2005), IUCLID (2000).).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: The chemical structure of the substance does not contain metals or metaloids(B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement:
Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (blood system)
May cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (liver, kidney)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Though effects on blood systems, liver, kidney were seen (RTECS (2004)), viewed from a guidance value, it is classified in Category 1 for blood system, and Category 2 for liver and kidney .

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification:
Category 1 (central nervous system, blood system, kidney, liver, respiratory system),
Category 3 (narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement:
Causes damage to organs (central nervous system, blood system, kidney, liver, respiratory system)
May cause drowsiness or dizziness (narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Since the effects to the central nervous system, cardiovascular systems, renal, lung, and liver in human are observed (DFGOT vol.5 (1993)), it is classified into Category 1. Since there is the description which irritates the airway seriously (ICSC (J) (2003)), together with the effect on lung, and the target organ is the respiratory systems. Moreover, since the anaesthetic by inhalations is indicated (DFGOT vol.5 (1993)), it is also classified into Category 3 (anaesthetic).
